tag.name: C1 - RULES ON SUBJECT LOAD
patterns: What are the rules on subject load
responses:
Rules on Subject Load:

No subject may be taken unless all prerequisite subjects have been taken and passed.

Upon the discretion of the Dean, non-graduating students may be allowed to enroll during summer classes with a maximum of nine (9) units to make up for the previously failed subject or to grant the student regular status upon passing it.

Subjects enrolled without the necessary prerequisite shall not be credited regardless of the grade obtained.

Students may be allowed to simultaneously enroll in prerequisite and advanced classes under the following conditions:

- If the prerequisite is a repeated subject
- If the student has a cumulative grade average of at least 2.25
- If the student is graduating at the end of the school term
- If it is approved by the Dean/Vice Dean or any authorized academic official or by the CHED or TESDA as the case may be.

Laboratory subjects that are paired with academic subjects should be taken during the same semester as the academic subject even if separate grades are given for both.

No student should be allowed to enroll in the 4th Year level unless he/she has taken and passed all PE and NSTP subjects.

tag.name: D1 - CHANGE OF REGISTRATION PROCEDURE
patterns: What are the procedures for adding/changing subjects
responses:
Change of Registration Procedure:

Secure and accomplish the Add or Change of Registration Form from the Frontline Office.

Proceed to the Dean's Office and have the form signed either by the College Dean or Vice Dean.

Pay the Add or Change of Registration fee at the College Finance Office.

Submit the form to the Registrar's Office to process the adding/changing of subject.

The student shall keep his/her copy of the form.

tag.name: E1 - ACCREDITATION OF SUBJECT PROCEDURE
patterns: What steps should a student take if they want to substitute or get accreditation for a subject?
How can I substitute or get accreditation for a subject?
Substitute or get accreditation for a subject
responses:
Procedure of Accreditation:

Secure and accomplish the substitution/accreditation form (3 copies) from the Registrar/Frontline office.

Proceed to the concerned faculty and Office of the Dean and have the form signed after evaluating the subjects applied for substitution/accreditation.

The Dean or Vice Dean shall endorse the approval to the Office of the Registrar to process the substitution/accreditation of subject.

tag.name: F1 - TUTORIAL SUBJECTS PROCEDURE
patterns: What are the procedures for tutorial subjects
How can I apply for tutorial subjects?
responses:
Tutorial Subjects Procedure:

The Dean or Vice Dean will evaluate applicants to determine their status. If a candidate for graduation, applicants will be asked to accomplish the Request for Tutorial Class Form. The certification of the Dean and evaluation should be attached to the request for the special class form.

For professional courses, the Dean or Vice Dean assigns faculty for the subject. For other courses, the request will be forwarded to the concerned College for proper assignment of faculty: College of Arts and Sciences for general education subjects and College of Computer Studies for computer informational technology subjects.

The Dean of the concerned College will endorse the request to the Office of the Registrar who in turn endorses the request to the Vice President for Academic Affairs (VPAA) for approval/disapproval.

If approved, applicants will pay the necessary fees to the College Finance Office.

The Finance Office will forward copies to the Office of the Registrar for distribution.

tag.name: G - SUBJECT PETITION
patterns: How can they ensure that the course content of the subject they want to substitute/accredit is similar to the one they're requesting?
How can I petition for a subject?
responses: Students who are under-loaded may submit a petition letter to the Dean's Office indicating the number of students interested in enrolling the course (not less than 15 otherwise the course will not be offered). If the course has been approved, the students will accomplish a waiver that they are going to pay for a class of 15 students.

tag.name: H1 - DROPPING AND WITHDRAWAL PROCEDURE
patterns: What are the steps for students to completely withdraw or drop all subjects?
How can I withdraw from all my subjects?
responses:
Dropping and Withdrawal Procedure:

• Secure a Dropping Form at the Frontline Office.

• Present written consent of parents or guardian and accomplished dropping form to the College Dean or Vice Dean for approval.

• Present approved Dropping Form to the College Finance Office for payment of dropping fee and/or tuition fee payment as per Finance Office policy.

• Present duly approved Dropping Form to the College concerned for notation and information of its faculty.

Students who withdraw from the College without formal leave of absence shall apply for readmission as new students.

tag.name: I1 - LOA PROCEDURE
patterns: How long is the allowed duration for a leave of absence (LOA) according to the policy
How can I apply for a leave of absence?
What is the procedure for taking a leave of absence?
responses:
Leave of Absence Procedure:

Students who are applying for a Leave of Absence (LOA) should write a letter to the Dean or Vice Dean of their respective college indicating the reason(s) for the LOA. Parent consent/guardian and other pertinent document/s to support the reason should likewise be submitted.

Once the Dean or Vice Dean has approved the letter, students will be advised to fill-up the LOA form from the Frontline Office.

Students forward the form to the Office of the Registrar for approval and safekeeping.

tag.name: J1 - RE-ADMISSION PROCEDURE
patterns: What is the procedure for students who withdraw from the college without obtaining a formal leave of absence?
How can I apply for re-admission?
Procedure for re-enrolling after withdrawing without leave
responses:
Re-admission Procedure:

Students who have undergone a LOA without the required application will need to file for a re-admission and pay a re-admission fee.

Students applying for re-admission need to submit a letter to the College Dean or Vice Dean they intend to re-enroll. Once the letter is noted, the student will be advised to pay the re-admission fee to the corresponding finance office.

After payment, students request the Re-admission Form from the Frontline Office to be filled in and further secure the signature of the College Dean, and later forwarded to the Office of the Registrar for approval and safekeeping.

tag.name: K1 - CROSS ENROLMENT
patterns: Under what circumstances may a student be allowed to cross-enroll at another school?
How can I cross-enroll at another school?
responses:
Cross Enrollment Procedure:

Write a request letter to cross-enroll to the Dean or Vice Dean.

Submit the letter duly signed by the Dean or Vice Dean to the Office of the Registrar for official transmittal to the school where the student wishes to cross-enroll.

tag.name: ACADEMIC CALENDAR
patterns: When does the summer class typically take place?
What is the structure of the academic year, including the duration of each semester and the summer session?
what is the academic year structure?
When do the first and second semesters start and end?
When does the summer class typically take place?
responses:
The Academic Year (AY) is consisting of two (2) semesters of at least 18 weeks each semester including legal and special holidays.

A summer session of six (6) weeks follows the second semester. Each semestral or summer term consists of 54 hours of formal classroom instruction and periodic examinations.

The first semester starts in August and ends in December while the second semester begins in January and ends in May. Summer class starts in June and ends in July or August.

tag.name: ATTENDANCE AND PUNCTUALITY  - TARDINESS
patterns: How are tardiness and absences handled?
responses: Students shall be marked tardy if they arrived within 15 minutes in a class. Beyond that period, they will be marked absent.

tag.name: ATTENDANCE AND PUNCTUALITY  - ABSENCES
patterns: How are tardiness and absences handled?
is there an exemption for absence
responses:
Students shall not be given credit in any course if the number of their absences exceeds (20%) of the total class hours required. However, upon the Dean's discretion, may exempt students who exceed the 20% limit on allowable absences for reasons considered valid and acceptable to the College.

Nonetheless, the exemption shall not excuse the concerned students from their responsibilities to keep up with missed lessons, comply with assignments and take examinations, where applicable.

tag.name: ATTENDANCE AND PUNCTUALITY  - EXCUSED ABSENCES
patterns: What circumstances qualify for excused absences?
how to be excused for absences
how to be exempted for absences
requirements to be excused for absence
responses:
Excused absences are limited to the following:
• Being indisposed due to severe illness or accident, certified by the students' attending physician.
• Other special cases deemed meritorious by the Dean, Vice Dean and approved by the Vice President for Academic Affairs.

The maximum number of accumulated absent hours that can be tolerated are the following:
• 5-unit subject - 18 class hours
• 4-unit subject - 14 class hours
• 3-unit subject - 11 class hours
• 2-unit subject - 7 class hours
• 1-unit subject - 4 class hours

tag.name: SPECIAL EXAM - PERMIT
patterns: Where and how do i get a special examination permit?
Where can i get special exam permit?
How to get special exam permit
What are the steps for special exam permit?
responses:
Special examination is given to a student who fails to take major examinations due to illness and other reasons deemed valid and justifiable.
• Students must pay special examination fee and whatever tuition fee due at the Finance Office before allowing them to take the special examination.
• Application for special examination must be approved by the Dean or Vice Dean of the student.
• Approved special examinations must be given not later than two (2) weeks for the regular 18-week semester and within the module schedule for modular approach.
• Failure to take the special examination will mean a score of zero.

tag.name: PRESIDENT'S LISTER
patterns: How to qualify for the President's List?
how to be in president's lister
how to be in president lister
how to get in president's lister
how to get in president lister
how to qualify in president's lister
how to qualify in president lister
how to be in dean's lister
how to be in dean lister
how to get in dean's lister
how to get in dean lister
how to qualify in dean's lister
how to qualify in dean lister
responses:
Starting Academic Year 2023-2024, DYClans with exceptional academic performance at the College Department will be recognized as President's Lister. This is an honor bestowed upon DYClans that acknowledges their outstanding dedication to their studies and exceptionally high General Weighted Average (GWA).

To qualify for the President's List, DYClans need to meet these specific criteria set by the academic community:

• Minimum GWA: Students are required to achieve a minimum GWA of 1.75, which is often significantly higher than the average GWA for all students.

    Sapientia: 1.00 to 1.25 GWA
    Excellentia: 1.26 to 1.50 GWA
    Virtus: 1.51 to 1.75 GWA

• Course Load: Students must have a regular course load based on the CHED contents-noted curriculum of the program he/she is currently enrolled.

• No Grade Lower Than: Students must have received no grades lower than 2.0 (new curriculum) or 2.25 (old curriculum).

• No Incomplete Grades: Students must have no incomplete grades to be eligible for the President's List.

• Status: Primarily, full-time students are eligible for this academic recognition. For irregular students, they must have completed a minimum of 18 units and above.

The academic community celebrates these academic achievements during the Via Ad Sapientiam The College Recognition Day once every semester.

tag.name: INCOMPLETE GRADES - WHAT
responses: An Incomplete grade (INC) is given to a student with a good class standing throughout a semester but fails to take any major examination or submit final course requirements on or before the scheduled dates.

tag.name: INCOMPLETE GRADES - COMPLETION OF INC
patterns: process for completing an incomplete grade
responses:
Secure completion form from the Frontline Office.

Pay the completion fee at the Finance Office.

Submit the completion Form with the attached receipts to the Office of the Dean.

The Office of the Dean endorses the completion form to the faculty member who will issue completion requirements.

The faculty returns the accomplished completion form to the College Dean for signature, then forwards it to the Office of the Registrar.

Removal of incomplete grade should be within six (6) months after the releasing of grades, otherwise, the grade shall automatically become 5.0 (Failure).

tag.name: RECOMPUTATION OF GRADES - WHAT
responses: Once the grades are posted in portal by the faculty and approved already by the Dean and Registrar, the faculty can no longer change them. Students may request for re- computation of grades/ratings through the Dean and Vice Dean of their college within six (6) months after the release of official grades.

tag.name: RECOMPUTATION OF GRADES - PROCEDURE (STUDENT)
patterns: recomputation of grades procedure for students
responses:
Submit a written request for re-computation of grades/ratings to the Office of the Dean.

The Dean or Vice Dean of the concerned college notifies the faculty who handled the course regarding the student's request for re-computation of grade/rating and deliberates on the request. If the concerned faculty is no longer connected with the College, the Dean reviews the submitted class record.

The Dean or Vice Dean of the concerned college transmits the notarized request for change of grades/correction of ratings to the Office of the Registrar with his recommendation/comments on the request.

The Registrar, based on the submitted documents, decides and recommends approval or disapproval of the request to the Vice President for Academic Affairs (VPAA).

The Registrar updates the student's file if the request is acted upon favorably.

tag.name: RECOMPUTATION OF GRADES - PROCEDURE (FACULTY)
patterns: recomputation of grades procedure for faculty
recomputation of grades procedure for professors
responses:
Faculty may request for change of grades/ correction of ratings to the Office of the Registrar through the Dean or Vice Dean of the concerned college within six (6) months after the official release of grades.

• Submit a notarized written request to the Office of the Dean of the concerned college stating the reason(s) why the grade of a particular student has to be changed or corrected.
• The Dean or Vice Dean of the concerned college transmits the notarized request for change of grades/ correction of ratings to the Office of the Registrar with his recommendation/comments on the request.
• The Registrar, based on submitted documents, decides and recommends approval and/or disapproval of the request to the Vice President for Academic Affairs (VPAA).
• The Registrar updates the student's file if the request of the faculty is acted upon favorably.

tag.name: APPLICATION FOR GRADUATION
responses:
No students shall be recommended for graduation unless he/she has satisfied all the academic and other requirements prescribed for graduation.

All graduating students must have their deficiencies made up and their records cleared not later than three (3) months before the end of their last semester, with the exception of those subjects in which the student is currently enrolled during the semester.

Graduating students must file the prescribed application for graduation together with their evaluation of grades and units earned to the Office of the Registrar at the end of the first semester of the preceding year before graduation.

This is to address all the deficiencies found and incurred by the student for the past years as well as advise the student on the courses to take during the second semester.

tag.name: APPLICATION FOR GRADUATION - PROCEDURE
patterns: What are the procedure for graduation?
responses:
• Accomplish Application to Graduate form from the Frontline Office.
• Pay the corresponding fee to the Finance Office and attach the official receipt to the form.
• Verify clearance from necessary faculty and Dean or Vice Dean before submitting to the Office of the Registrar.

Only those who have submitted their Graduation Confirmation and their Exit Clearance will be included in the Final List of Graduating Students for that academic year.
The Final List of Graduating Students will be indorsed to the respective Colleges by the Office of the Registrar for posting and information dissemination to their respective students.
The Final List of Students - Candidates for Latin Honors and other awards will then be submitted to the Board of Trustees for final approval and execution.

tag.name: GRAD HONORS AND AWARDS - LATIN HONORS
patterns: What are the Graduating Latin Honors
how to be a latin honor
responses:
Summa Cum Laude: General Weighted Average of 1.00 to 1.25, with no grade lower
than 1.50 in any academic subject

Magna Cum Laude: General Weighted Average of 1.26 to 1.50; with no grade lower
than 1.75 in any academic subject

Cum Laude: General Weighted Average of 1.51 to 1.75;
with no grade lower than 2.0 in
any academic subject
No candidate for Latin honors shall have a failing grade, incomplete, or dropped
status in any course nor shall have been involved in serious infraction of any law or
any school regulation.
Candidates for graduation with honors must have completed their respective
courses in the school with at least 75% of the total number of academic units
or hours required for graduation or they must have taken not less than 18
units every normal semestral load prescribed in the curriculum
In case of students graduating with honors, in degree programs which the
prescribed length is shorter than four (4) years, the English equivalent, With
Honors, With High Honors and With Highest Honors, shall be used instead.

tag.name: GRAD HONORS AND AWARDS - COLLEGE EXCELLENCE AWARD
patterns: What is the academic excellence award in college?
responses:
• Given to graduating students who earned a weighted average with that of the Latin Honors but with grades in his/her academic courses that are lower than what are specified above.

• Students receiving this award must not have grades lower than 2.25 in any of their academic courses.

tag.name: GRAD HONORS AND AWARDS - SPECIAL AWARD
patterns: What is the special award given by DYCI for graduates?
responses:
• Dr. Ismael E. Yanga, Sr., Leadership Award: given to graduates who have made valuable contributions to the institution and to the community through consistent and outstanding performance in the academic and institutional extra-curricular areas provided that the student has no disciplinary record and the GWA is at least 2.00. There may be more than one recipient of this award.

• Sofia Yanga Academic Excellence Award: Given to only one graduating student by the Academic Council in accordance with the following conditions: If there is no qualified recipient of Latin Honors in the Graduating batch,the award shall be given to the graduate with the highest GWA. The recipient must have no disciplinary case and his/her GWA is not less than 1.75. If there are several recipients of Latin Honors, the award shall be given to the Latin Honors Awardee with the highest distinction and GWA.

• Dr. Marciano D. Yanga Journalism Excellence Award: Given to a graduating student who has been an Editor-In-Chief of the institutional student newsletter for one or more academic year and has actively performed his task and contributed in the publication of the newsletter.

• Dr. Marciano D. Yanga Excellence Award in Robotics Technology: Given to graduating students who had shown exemplary performance in Robotics Technology and had represented the country in international robotics competition.

• Dr. Elida D. Yanga Research Excellence Award: Given to graduating students who had produced outstanding research work that reflects the values of the school and attribute of excellence, transcending the boundaries of research to regional, national, and international recognition.

responses: Students who obtain failing grades of more than 75% of their enrolled units shall be dropped from the roll.

tag.name: DISCOUNT - FRESHMEN

qualifying for a freshmen tuition discount
responses:
Incoming freshmen with an average of 90% or higher posted in their Grade 12 report card (F-138) shall be entitled to 15% discount on tuition fee for the first semester.

The number of graduating students from previous school must be at least 100 students to qualify for this discount privilege.

tag.name: DISCOUNT - DYCI HIGHSCHOOL ALUMNI

discount for DYCI high school graduates
responses:
Graduates of the DYCI High School shall be entitled to the following discounts based on their length of stay:

• Grade 7 to Grade 12 - 40% tuition fee discount
• Grade 8 to Grade 12 - 35% tuition fee discount
• Grade 9 to Grade 12 - 30% tuition fee discount
• Grade 10 to Grade 12 - 25% tuition fee discount
• Grade 11 to Grade 12 - 20% tuition fee discount

The student must have no outstanding financial obligation to continue the discount privilege.

Automatic forfeiture of the alumni discount privilege is in order the moment the alumni students transfer to another school even for one semester only.

responses:
The requirements for solo parents discount are:
- Submission of a photocopy of Solo parent ID with specimen signature.
- Photocopy of the student's PSA-issued birth certificate.
- And it must be done to the Office of the Student Affairs and Services - Scholarship.

tag.name: DISCOUNT - SIBLING
patterns: What conditions need to be met for the discount to be granted for siblings discount?
How can siblings qualify for a discount
criteria for availing a discount for siblings
requirements for granting a siblings discount
responses: This discount is granted if two or three siblings are all currently enrolled in DYCI during the same semester. Each sibling is entitled to 10% tuition fee discount. For purposes of availing this discount, each applicant (who must not be the sons/daughters of a DYCI employee) must submit photocopy of the PSA certified birth certificate and proof of enrollment at DYCI of the sibling/s.

tag.name: DISCOUNT - EMPLOYEE
patterns: What is the employee discount policy at DYCI?
details of the employee discount policy work at DYCI
responses:
Relatives of DYCI employees, whose employment status is permanent/regular, shall be entitled to tuition fee discount as follows:
• Spouse - 50%
• Children - 50%
• Sibling - 25%
The employee must submit a photocopy of the PSA certified birth certificate (in cases of children and sibling discount) or PSA certified marriage contract (in case of spouse discount).
Moreover, automatic forfeiture of the employee discount privilege is also in order the moment the spouse, child, or sibling transfers to another school even for one semester only or if the employee resigns from DYCI.
Finally, this discount benefit is limited to one sibling at any given time.

responses: The OSAS is dedicated to fostering a vibrant and inclusive campus community that enriches the academic journey of each DYClan. As the heart of campus life, the OSAS serves as a compass guiding students through their holistic development, ensuring a well-rounded and transformative DYCI experience. responses:
• Responsible for supervision, monitoring, and evaluation of activities of different clubs and organizations duly recognized by the institution.
• Guides the student-led organizations to ensure that their objectives and activities are in accordance with the institution's vision and mission statements, and initiating and enhancing leadership skills and social responsibility.
• Provide opportunities for students to develop and enhance their leadership skills and potential.

responses:
DYCI recognizes that in order to provide a holistic development among its students and develop well-rounded individuals, academic training should be complemented with meaningful co- and extra-curricular activities.
• Co-curricular Organizations
Students of each college automatically become members of their respective co-curricular organization.
• Extra-curricular Organizations
For the extracurricular organizations, membership is open to all interested students who would like to develop their talents and skills. Some organizations screen their applicants by holding auditions.
⚬ Brass Band
⚬ Campus Ministry
⚬ Dagalak
⚬ Dr. Yanga Dance Alliance
⚬ Peer Facilitators Club
New clubs or organizations shall only be approved and recognized after completing the requirements and meeting the conditions set by the OSAS Student Affairs Unit.
To apply for a new club / organization, submit a letter of intent together with the name of recommended moderator. The letter must be recommended by the Dean and Vice Dean.
Two copies of the By-Laws of the proposed organization with objectives aligned to the Vision and Mission statements of DYCI.
List of officers and plan of activities.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - Policies and Procedures for In-campus and Off-campus Activities
patterns: Can you tell me about the policies for off-campus activities?

Can you tell me about the rules for off campus activities?

responses:
Application for any in-campus or off-campus activity must be filed by the Organizational President and Adviser at the OSAS Student Affairs Unit at least two weeks before the activity.
The application form must be reviewed by the respective Dean and Vice Dean regarding the relevance of the activity, compliance to CHED requirements, and policies of external agencies may it be public or private.

The proposal form must have the following attachments:
• Proof of student consultation
• Breakdown of projected expenses
• List of involved students and faculty
• Approved program flow or schedule by the Office of the Dean Communication letter to relevant internal offices or units especially the Health Services Unit and Security and Safety Unit.
• Parental waiver and consent letter if the activity extends beyond 8:00 pm or will fall during Sundays or declared holidays
• For off-campus activity with third party service providers, a Memorandum of Agreement for the partner travel agencies, tour operators, vehicle and transportation providers, training providers, and others.
• Compliance to CHED Memorandum Order (CMO) No. 63, Series of 2017, Policies and Guidelines for Local Off- campus Activity or any updated and relevant CMO issued by the Commission.
• Permit from the Local Government Units (LGUs), and/ or national agencies if applicable.
• Parallel Activity Plan for non- participating students, if applicable
Submitted proposal and documents shall be reviewed and approved by the Office of Student Affairs and Services Director and the Vice President for Academic Affairs (VPAA).
Any payments necessary for the in- or off-campus activity shall be only at the Finance and Accounting Office.
Complete documentation of the activity should be submitted to OSAS Student Affairs Unit within two weeks after the activity.
• Approved activity proposal with attachments
• Attendance and registration
• Accomplishment and narrative reports
• Pictures with captions
• Financial report
• Accomplished evaluation forms

responses:
Need help about health issues? You can go ask the Health Services Unit

As they plan, develops, implements, and delivers quality medical and dental services to students and employees.
Ensures student health needs are met and health barriers to learning are properly addressed.
Services provided by the Health Services Unit include:
⚬ First aid for acute illness and injury
⚬ Medical and dental check-up
⚬ Pre-participation medical and dental examinations for athletes
⚬ Medical health counseling
⚬ Provision of information relevant to students' concerns such as but not limited to physical fitness, weight management, acne, menstrual concerns, dental issues, and others.
Students with ongoing classes who come to the clinic must present a referral letter/slip from the concerned faculty member/instructor except for emergency cases.
Parents or guardians shall be contacted to come to school and fetch the students who are ill and are unable to return to class. Likewise, referral to another health facility shall be given if deemed necessary.
In case of acute illness or minor injury not needing emergent medical attention, the client shall be cared for by the HSU staff until the parents/guardians arrive. First aid shall be provided.
In case of major injuries/illness, first aid shall be administered and after careful assessment and evaluation, the student shall be brought immediately to the hospital. Parents and guardian shall be notified immediately.
Clients diagnosed of having communicable disease (i.e, COVID-19, influenza-like illness, etc,) should present to the school clinic a medical clearance from a licensed doctor before being allowed to resuming attendance of classes.
Officially enrolled students may avail of the following benefits for hospitalization at the Dr. Yanga's Hospital (DYH), Bocaue, Bulacan:
⚬ 20% discount in room accommodation Discount on doctor's fee if he/she is admitted under the care of a DYCI Health Services Physician. The services of non- DYCI Health Services attending physician consultants are NOT included in this discount.
⚬ 10% discount on laboratory procedures (excluding CT-Scan)
⚬ 50% Discount on doctor's fee if he/she is seen and treated by DYH resident on duty.
All students are protected for by an updated insurance coverage. To apply for insurance coverage, the guardian or student must inform and submit the required documents at Health Services Unit within 30 days from the date of accident. The approval/granting of such privileges is entirely up to the third-party insurance provider.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - C. THE SOFIA LIBRARY
patterns: Can you tell me about SOFIA LIBRARY

I would like to know about SOFIA LIBRARY
responses: Library services for college students are provided by The Sofia, featuring flexible learning spaces that encourage collaboration, communication, and sharing among teachers and students, serving as an information hub for networking, content creation, and independent learning, while also collecting and maintaining physical and virtual resources supporting instruction, research, and community extension.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - C.1. Entry and Departure
patterns: rules for entering and leaving the library
responses:
• Students are required to log-in and log-out to the attendance system using their identification card upon entry and departure into The Sofia.
• The identification card must be worn within the library premises and presented for all transactions in the library.
• The Chief Librarian or any member of The Sofia has the right to request any person within the premises to present his/her ID or to confiscate it for violation of library rules.
• Anybody caught using the ID of another person to gain entry into, to borrow materials from, or to avail of other library services may be recommended for disciplinary action by the Librarian.
• Unauthorized taking out of the library materials is a violation of the library's rules and regulations.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - C.2. Borrowing
patterns: How do I borrow books from the library, and are there any rules or procedures I need to follow?
rules in borrowing books from library
responses:
• Only enrolled students and employed faculty, professionals, administrators, and staff of DYCI may borrow materials from The Sofia after presenting a valid identification card.
• Only books from the general circulation and Filipiniana may be borrowed for home use. Other materials may only be used within the library.
• The number of books that may be borrowed and the duration of the loan depend on the classification of the user.
• PATRON TYPE - NO. OF BOOKS - LOAN DURATION
• Students - 3 books - 1 week
• Teaching staff and administrators - 10 books - 2 weeks
• Non-teaching staff - 5 books - 2 weeks
• *May be extended the whole semester if the teaching staff uses it as a reference book for subject/s handled.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - C.3. Remote Access
patterns: How can I access the library's online resources remotely
responses:
• Password for remote access to online resources is issued only to currently enrolled students, faculty members, professionals, administrators, and staff.
• Users of the DYCI Library's online resources must not divulge or give away the user IDs and passwords to other individuals.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - C.4. Library Fines and Lost Items
patterns: What are the fines for overdue books
what should I do if I lose a library item
are there any fees for lost or damaged items?
responses: • Overdue books will be charged five pesos (Php 5.00) per book per day exclusive of Sundays, holidays and suspension of classes. If an item is lost, the library should be notified immediately. All library patrons are responsible for the replacement of the lost items plus the accumulated overdue fines. Lost books must be replaced with the same title, edition and author. If the patron found the book after being declared or reported lost and returns it, and if the book is in good condition, the patron will be required to pay only the accumulated overdue fine. Lost book should be replaced within a week after it has been reported lost. Processing fee of Two Hundred Pesos (Php 200.00) will be added to the cost. Brokerage / shipping fee of five hundred pesos (Php 500.00) is added for books purchased abroad.

responses:
The DYCI Center for Community Engagement envisions itself to be the dynamic and proactive implementer, advocate and promoter of significant, sustainable and strategic programs of Dr. Yanga's Colleges, Inc., in three focal areas - PAmayanan (community), paaRAlan (public school system) and parokYA (church) of the society it yearns to serve and in the process, instilling the innate Filipino value of PARAYA among the students, faculty, staff and key stakeholders as they pursue the mission of service to the least, the last and the lost.
• Impact community (PAmayanan) through adopt-a-barangay program and adopt-a-sector program like the senior citizens of a particular barangay through health assistance, values education, and even capability-building programs;
• Involve the DYClan family to uplift the public school system (PaaRAlan) through varied programs of feeding, computer literacy, robotics education, and values enhancement programs;
• Immerse the DYClan family and forge strong partnership with the Church (ParokYA), which reaches down to the grassroot level, in its formation and socio-economic programs through health assistance, capability building, talent sharing in arts and music, value education and assistance the marginalized sectors that the Church continuously serves.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - G. QUALITY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM OFFICE (QMSO)

responses:
The QMSO is responsible for establishing, maintaining, and continuously improving the organization's quality management framework. It focuses on ensuring that products, services, and processes meet or exceed established quality standards, resulting in customer satisfaction, compliance with regulations, and overall organizational excellence.
It focuses on three key aspects: the people (including students and staff), the processes we use (how we teach and organize things), and the systems we have in place (to make the people and the processes work effectively and efficiently).
For concerns and feedback, click the codes below:
Concerns Form:
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSck3ZBsmgM4niGus0NsJzZXVOPIVoYWMbL6r8Z9YbkidOqnRg/viewform
Feedback Form:
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScDW6qvyiLUBNxrUcFk_u2jvXXaG24sOAyysLLZWP73x50gBw/viewform
This system aims to gather feedback, concerns, and suggestions from all members of our DYClan community. By clicking the provided QR codes with their smartphones, stakeholders can easily access a secure platform where they can express their thoughts on various aspects of the school.
Your feedback is of utmost importance to us, as it enables continuous improvement in all areas, including academics, facilities, support services, and more. Together, we can work collaboratively to enhance the college experience for everyone involved.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - H. THE LABORATORIES
patterns: What are the rules and regulations for using the school laboratories
what are the rules for using the laboratory
what are the rules for using the lab
safety protocols and proper conduct within the school laboratories?
is permission needed to enter laboratories
responses:
• Students may only enter the laboratories if the laboratory technician or faculty assigned is present.
• Students are expected to act responsibly and accordingly in all laboratories at all times. Students entering any laboratory should be wearing the prescribed uniform or the mandated laboratory attire.
• Students and faculty are expected to observe the proper use and care of the laboratory instruments, devices and other equipment so as to avoid damage. All materials or equipment used must be returned to their proper places before leaving the laboratory. Any damage should be immediately reported to the respective persons in charge of the laboratory.
• Strictly no eating and drinking in all laboratories.
• Using of any laboratory room for private or personal purposes is not allowed.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - H.1. COMPUTER LABORATORY
responses:
There are four (4) main computer laboratories in which faculty, students and staff from different programs may have the opportunity to widen and improve their computer skills and knowledge, and apply them in every possible way to achieve academic excellence. These are the following:
• College Computer Laboratory
• The Lab at the Simulation Room
• The SparkLab
• CME Computer Laboratory

DYCI maintains its standard ratio of one computer unit to one student, so that all students can maximize their potential in learning computer-related subjects.
Only authorized personnel / staff are permitted to install, uninstall, and make any modification on any computer unit
Students are not allowed to attach their own gadget to any computer units without the expressed permission of the faculty or system administrator.
Students are not permitted to attempt repair, calibrate or modify any equipment in a laboratory at any time.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - H.2. THE ROBOLAB
responses: College students with robotics-related subjects in their curriculum uses the DYCI RoboLab. It is specialized facility equipped with advanced tools, equipment, and technology to facilitate research, development, experimentation, and education in the field of robotics. It serves as a hub for students, researchers, and enthusiasts to explore the design, construction, programming, and application of robotic systems. The laboratory provides an environment for hands-on learning, experimentation, and innovation in robotics technology.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - H.3. SCIENCE LABORATORIES
responses:
There are seven (7) science laboratories for different degree programs Natural Science, Physics, Chemistry, Microbiology, Anatomy, Nutrition, and Nursing Skills. These are venues for the theoretical applications, scientific investigations, experiments and skills trainings of students.

• Borrowing and returning of glassware, apparatuses and equipment is subject to availability and approval of the Dean or Vice Dean of the college.
• Request for laboratory chemicals and reagents must be one (1) week before date of use to the laboratory personnel as noted by the Dean or Vice Dean.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - I. CANTEEN SERVICES
responses:
The school canteen along with other food stalls inside the campus, serve as a venue to provide students and the DYCI community with quality, affordable food choices by maintaining a safe area for eating, providing nutritious meals, and potable water by maintaining high standards of hygiene in the preparation and handling food and drinks.

Courtesy in dealing with canteen personnel must be always observed. Food wrappers, plastics and styrofoam products must be thrown in the trash cans.
The canteen must be used solely as a place for eating. Students who want to do school work or other activities may either go to the library or student lounge. Show consideration for others by vacating the table immediately after dining.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - J. FINANCE AND ACCOUNTING OFFICE
responses:
There are two (2) Finance and Accounting Office for college students to settle their financial obligations. First, the College Finance and Accounting Office (CFAO) for Arts and Sciences, Accountancy, Business Administration, Computer Studies, Education, Health Sciences, and Psychology. Second, the CME Finance and Accounting Office (CME FAO) for Hospitality Management and Tourism, Maritime Education, and Mechanical Engineering.
All fees are payable in advance. Installment payments may be arranged according to the following schedule:
• If upon enrollment 50% of total fees is paid, the balance is payable in four (4) equal monthly payments
• If upon enrollment 25% of total fees is paid, the balance is still payable in four (4) equal monthly payments with additional finance charge of 10% computed based on gross amount payable.
Demand letters shall be sent to students for balances not settled in the previous semesters. Students must settle their outstanding balance before enrollment.
Students and parents or guardians may view financial records through OSIRIS, the student portal for grades and payments.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - J.2. TUITION REFUND
responses:
• A student who withdraws in writing before the opening of classes is entitled to a refund in the amount equivalent to 100% of the tuition and other fees except for the Registration fee.
• During the first week of classes, the refund shall be of the amount equivalent to 75% for CHED courses, 90% for TESDA courses of the tuition, and other fees except the Registration fee and ID fee.
• During the second week of classes, the refund shall be of the amount equivalent to 50% for CHED courses, 80% for TESDA courses of the tuition and other fees except Registration fee and ID fee
• After the second week of classes, no refund shall be charged for all school fees. If students have fully paid their fees and are opting to cancel, they shall be entitled to a refund equivalent to the amount of the course less the 5% discount provided for the amount..
• The time allotted for refund will be based on the approved change of registration slip received in the Office of the Registrar or the Dean.
• Students are not considered officially enrolled unless they have paid the first installment due on tuition fees and miscellaneous fees.

tag.name: STUDENT SERVICES AND CAMPUS LIFE - J.3. LATE CHARGE FEE
patterns: what happens if i enrolled two weeks after the start of class
responses: A penalty fee shall be charged to a student who enrolled two weeks after the start of classes.

tag.name: GENERAL DECORUM
patterns: What are the key behavior and conduct guidelines for DYCI students?
responses:
I. Upholding the DYCIAN Values
The DYCI aims to have graduates who are God-centered, value-driven, self-directed, disciplined, and responsible. Thus, it expects its students to uphold these values in all places at all times.

II. Observance of Simplicity and Decency at All Times.
Each DYCI student represents the institution and is therefore expected to carry himself/herself with dignity and must observe simplicity and decency in deeds, words, and appearance whether inside or outside the school campus.

III. Observance of Honesty and Good Interpersonal Relationships.
Each DYCI student is expected to observe honesty, courtesy, respect, and cheerfulness in his or her dealings with any person.

IV. Participation in School Activities.
Students are encouraged to participate in the school's institutional, co-curricular, and extra-curricular activities.

V. Observance of Good Manners.
The usual norms of etiquette should always be observed in dealing with administrators, faculty members, and school staff during school activities at all places and times.

VI. Respect for the National Anthem and School Hymn.
Whenever the National Anthem or the DYCI Hymn is played, all students, faculty, and staff of DYCI should stand and sing out of respect.

VII. Showing of Concern for The School and Its Facilities.
Each DYCI student is expected to show personal respect and concern for the school by maintaining the cleanliness and orderliness of its facilities and premises including classrooms, corridors, comfort rooms, and canteens.

VIII. Being Considerate with Others.
Conversations whether in the classroom, corridors, or waiting sheds should be modulated so as not to call attention or attract other people. Avoid boisterous conduct, loud laughter, or actions that are distracting. Obscene or cursing words including green jokes must be avoided at all times.

IX. Obedience and Conformance with DYCI Standards.
Each DYCI student is expected to conform to the standards of responsible behavior set by the institution.

tag.name: ARTICLE 4 - SEC 1 EXPULSION
patterns: process and consequence of expulsion for a student found guilty of serious misconduct
responses:
Expulsion: an extreme form of administrative sanction given to a student who has
committed serious or grave misconduct. Such penalty shall bar the enrollment of the
student to all public or private schools in the Philippines. Expulsion will become effective
upon its approval of the Regional Director of CHED The fact of expulsion shall be recorded
in the student's official Transcript of Record.

A student under investigation of a case involving the penalty of expulsion may be preventively
suspended from entering the school premises if the evidence of guilt is strong and the
school head is morally convinced that the continued stay of the student during the period of
investigation constitutes a distraction to the normal operations of the school or poses a risk
or danger to the life of the persons or property of the school

If the student is absolved of the charges though he is not entitled to make up for the days lost,
he shall be allowed to take the examinations, quizzes and graded recitations missed

ARTICLE V - Violations on which sanctions are applicable
Sec. 1 Academic Integrity
a. Any form of cheating furning quizzes, asses and examinations
and/or aiding and/or abetting others to cheat (Class D)
b. Any form of plagiarism such as using someone else's ideas, words, work or
intellectual property without proper attribution or authorization and presenting them as one's
own during any graded academic activity. This includes copying and pasting text, images,
data. or any other form of content from sources such as books, articles, websites,
or other students' work without giving appropriate credit (Class D)
c. Falsification of academic records by altering, forging, or misrepresenting official
scores, grade or result of any graded assessment (Class D)
d. Academic dishonesty in research projects involves the intentional misrepresentation
or falsification of research data, findings, results, or methodologies in order to deceive or

Sec. 2 Attendance and Punctuality

tag.name: STUDENT CODE OF DISCIPLINE - ARTICLE 6
patterns: What is Implementation of Disciplinary Action
process for investigating and implementing disciplinary actions
responses:
ARTICLE VI - Manner of Investigation and Implementation of Disciplinary Action
Sec. 1. The investigation is essentially fact-finding.
Its specific purpose is to determine on the basis of the evidence gathered, the innocence or guilt of the student
concerned who would be informed thereof accordingly.
Sec.2. Any student found to have committed a regulated act which is designated as
either a Class A or Class B offense shall be referred to the Prefect of Discipline.
The above notwithstanding, where the penalty involved is suspension from two (2) days to five
(5) days, the student shall be referred to the Prefect of Discipline
Where the student has been previously suspended for at least two (2) times, regardless of the
period of suspension or where the regulated act committed by the student falls under the
list of either Class D or Class E offerises, his case will be referred to the Student Discipline Committee
Sec.3. The following are the basic considerations in the conduct of the investigation.
Fact-Finding Pertinent evidence in support of the projected action against the student
concerned who is believed to have engaged or is engaged in any of the prohibited activities shall be gathered
Evaluation The evidence gathered relative to the innocence or guilt of the student concerned
shall be collated and evaluated preparatory for the formulation or promulgation
of the decision of the case
Decision The decision, based on the evidence gathered as evaluated, shall be reckoned vis--vis
the standard of preponderance of evidence, le that the presumptions in favor of the student concerned
are disputed or overruled by the evidence, provided however that when there is doubt regarding the guilt.
the student concerned may be called for purposes of confronting him with the evidence against
him and for him to explain his side, if possible after which a decision on the same case may be rendered
Disciplinary Action Certain factors shall also be taken into account in imposing disciplinary action upon an erring student such as the student's previous
record, the inherent gravity of the offense, character and position of the aggrieved person or the established precedent.
Sec.4. In cases referred to the Prefect of Discipline or any duly designated
representative or committee, the following steps will be followed
The Prefect of Discipline shall furnish the student a copy of the incident report and supporting statements
and/or documents, if any, which recept shall be acknowledged by the student in writing
The student concerned shall have the right to answer the charges against him/her, with the
assistance of counsel coming from the DYCI academic community if desired in writing and
submit the same and supporting statements and/or documents within twenty-four (24)
hours from receipt of the incident report. The written answer of the student must be signed
by any of his parents or guardian
To further familiarize himself/herself with the circumstances of the case, the Prefect of Discipline
may conduct formal queries with any department personnel or student involved
After consideration of all the evidence presented and available, the Prefect of Discipline shall
call the complaining student/s, the student/s complained of and their parents or guardian to
a conference. During said conference, the Prefect of Discipline shall present his/her
findings and the imposable sanction, if any. and will furnish the parties with written copies of the same.
The decision of the Prefect of Discipline shall include a directive that immediately after the
suspension, the student shall report to the OSAS Guidance and Counseling Unit for a
counseling session. The Prefect of Discipline's decision shall be final

tag.name: STUDENT CODE OF DISCIPLINE - ARTICLE 7
patterns: grave and serious misconduct of student
what are the student code of discipline
explain the role and process of the Student Discipline Committee
responses:
Article VII - Student Discipline Committee

Sec.1. The Student Discipline Committee ('the Committee') is designed to hear cases involving grave and serious misconduct of students. Its objectives are geared towards the promotion of proper behavior and respect and obedience for disciplinary regulations.

Sec.2 The Committee shall be composed of the Prefect of Discipline, who shall serve as the presiding officer College Dean or Vice Dean, and one faculty, student representatives.

Sec. 3. The cases referred to the Committee or any of its duly designated representatives or committee shall be dealt with in compliance with the following procedure:

• The complaining student, any of his parents or guardian, shall prepare a statement in writing in duplicate indicating the identity of the student complained of, the date, time and place of the incident, and a brief but clear description of the alleged misbehavior. This statement shall serve as a complaint. The complaint shall be supported by pertinent documents and statements of witnesses.

• Said copies of the statement and supporting documents shall be immediately forwarded to the Prefect of Discipline. Within twenty-four (24) hours from receipt of the said documents, the Prefect shall ensure that the student complained of shall have received a copy of the complaint and of the supporting documents, if any. The student shall acknowledge receipt of the said papers in writing.

• The student concerned shall answer the complaint in writing and submit the same and supporting statements and/or documents within twenty-four (24) hours from receipt. The written answer of the student must be signed by any of his parents or guardian.

• Within two (2) days from receipt of the answer of the student complained of, the Committee shall convene to conduct an initial evaluation of available evidence. Two (2) days after the initial evaluation, the Committee shall set a date for preliminary investigation. The Prefect shall ensure that written notices of the preliminary investigation shall have been received by the students concerned or any of their parents or guardian before the hearing date.

• During the preliminary investigation, the Committee may require the students concerned accompanied by their parents or guardian to answer clarificatory questions. The Committee may likewise interview the witnesses named by the parties.

• After considering all of the evidence available, the Committee shall make a written recommendation. Copies of such recommendation shall be forwarded to the Office of Student Affairs and Services (OSAS) Director and afterward the Vice President for Academic Affairs (VPAA) for further recommendation. Lastly, recommendations of the Committee, the Director of OSAS and the VPAA who will either approve or disapprove the recommendations.

• Within 2 days from receipt of the decision of the OSAS and the VPAA, the Prefect shall call the complaining students, the student/s complained of, and their parents or guardian to a conference. During said conference, the Prefect shall present the decision and the imposable sanction if any and will furnish the parties with written copies of the same.

For the protection of the parties, the whole investigation and the presentation of the decision shall not exceed a period of three (3) weeks from the time the complaint was received.

Within five (5) days from receipt of the decision of the VPAA, any party aggrieved by the same may file an appeal with the Office of the President whose decision shall be final.

tag.name: STUDENT CODE OF DISCIPLINE - ARTICLE 8
patterns: What is the process for students to file and resolve complaints
file complaints with faculty or staff
procedure for the settlement of complaints and grievances
responses:
Article VIII - Settlement of Complaints/Grievances between Students and Members of the Faculty and/or School Personnel

Sec. 1. The procedure for the settlement of complaints and grievances in the College shall conform with due process in order to ensure the highest degree of fairness and justice to all concerned. However, all concerned should seek to the fullest extent all remedies through informal conferences counseling mediation and other modes of amicable settlement of conflicts. In every case, the ultimate aim shall be the restoration of impaired human dignity and, where necessary, restoration of material damages.

Sec. 2. A grievance is any dissatisfaction, complaint, imitation, or misunderstanding by a student arising from his/her status as a student or his/her relationship with a faculty member, a non-teaching staff or an administrator within the institution.

Sec. 3. A complaining student may air his grievance either formally or informally

Sec. 4. The procedure for the informal settlement of a grievance is as follows:

• If the person complained of is a faculty member, the student shall approach the Dean or Vice Dean of the college where the faculty member belongs. In the case of non-teaching personnel, the student shall approach the head of his office/unit or the Director of the Office of Student Affairs and Services.

• The Dean / Vice Dean / head of office / unit shall call immediately the attention of the complained faculty or non-teaching personnel for his/her explanation.

• If needed, the Dean / Vice Dean / head of office / unit shall set an informal conference to give the student and the faculty member/non-teaching personnel an opportunity to clarify matters and settle issues.

• If the parties are able to settle their differences amicably, the Dean / Vice Dean / head of office / unit shall prepare a brief but clear report on the incident for records purposes. For the protection of the parties, such report shall be confidential, unless formally requested in relation with any investigation conducted by any of the school authorities. Should the parties fail to settle, the Dean / Vice Dean / head of office / unit shall advise the student to avail of formal grievance procedures

Sec. 5. The procedure for the formal settlement of a grievance is as follows:

• The complaining student or any of his parents or guardian shall prepare a statement in writing in duplicate indicating the identity of the faculty member or non-teaching personnel concerned the date time and place of the incident and a brief but clear description of the alleged misbehavior and submit to the Office of Student Affairs and Services (OSAS, This statement shall serve as a complaint If necessary the complaint may be supported by pertinent documents and statements of witnesses.

• Within two (2) days from receipt of the complaint the OSAS shall ensure that the person complained of shall have received copies of the same The person. complained of shall answer the complaint in writing and submit the same and supporting statements and/or documents within three (3) days from receipt.

• Upon receipt of the answer, the OSAS shall collate all the evidence available and within one week, shall convene the Ad Hoc Committee (the Committee) and set a date for a fact-finding hearing.

• The Committee shall be composed of (1) OSAS Director who shall act as the Chairman of the Committee, (II) Dean of the College to which the complainant belongs (II) Dean of the College or Office Director which the complained belongs (iv) the President of the student organization to which the complainant belongs. (v) the President of the Supreme Student Council, and. (vi) two members of the DYCI Faculty and Employees Association (DYCIFEA). one from the same College/Office to which the respondent faculty member/non-teaching personnel belongs and another member who is appointed by DYCIFEA (vii) and the Director of the Human Recourse Management and Development Office (HRMDO) In case any of the above is a party to the case, his place in the Committee will be taken over by another official representative of the sector, preferably the one next in line

• During the fact-finding hearing, the Committee may require the students concerned accompanied by their parents or guardian and the faculty member or non- teaching personnel complained of to answer clarificatory questions. The Committee may likewise interview the witnesses named by the parties.

• After the hearing, the Committee shall sit down and evaluate all available evidences and shall make a written recommendation. The Committee shall render their findings to the Vice President for Academic Affairs (VPAA) for faculty members, and the Vice President for Administration (VPAd) for non-teaching personnel, and to the Director of the Human Recourse Management and Development Office (HRMDO).

• Within two (2) days from receipt of the decision of the VPAA or the VPAd with the HRMDO Director, the OSAS shall furnish a written copy of the same to the parties.

• Within five (5) days from receipt of the decision of the VPAA or VPAd, any party aggrieved by the same may file an appeal with the Office of the President whose decision shall be final.

tag.name: PROMISORRY NOTE - GET
patterns: What are the steps to get promissory note

how can i get promissory note
responses:
To obtain a promissory note, follow these steps:

1. First, ensure that you have settled all your outstanding account obligations for the current semester.

2. Next, go to the Dean's Office of your Department and ask for a promissory form. You will need to bring your guardian along with you.

3. The Dean's Office will require a downpayment of at least ₱3,000, depending on your monthly balance.

4. You will also need to provide information on how much you plan to pay for the next term.

5. Once the Deans approve your request, you can obtain your Promissory Form.

Remember, it is important to settle your account obligations before requesting a promissory form.
